activityName: Chicken egg, poultry industrial laying systems, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
The present dataset is built according to GLEAM 2.0 methodology (FAO 2018). It uses housing and feed storage data gathered by Agroscope for the WFLDB version 3.4 and found in the following datasets: 'Laying hen, in barn single tiered, at farm (WFLDB 3.4)/CN U' and 'Rearing hen, at farm (WFLDB 3.4)/CN U'. The two systems are merged and scaled to represent the chicken husbandry.

The full description of the animal production system is available in the WFLDB documentation report: Bengoa X., Chappuis C., Guignard C., Liernur A., Kounina A., Papadimitriou C., Rossi V. & Bayart J-B.  (2019) World Food LCA Database Documentation. Version 3.5, November 2019. Quantis, Lausanne, Switzerland.

Reference flow: The total weight of chicken eggs laid  over one year in an industrial laying flock, at farm.

Included processes: The inventory includes the feed consumed by the total flock in one year, the laying and rearing hens husbandry systems and feed transport from regional warehouse to animal farm, enteric emissions and manure management emissions. At the end of the egg producing round the laying hen is assumed to be burned in municipal incineration. Duration of egg laying is 280 days, with 219 eggs produced

Geography: China

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.5   Good quality

Data sources:
- Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) (2018) Global Livestock Environmental Assessment Model, Model description Version 2.0.

activityName: Cured ham, 164g | Packaging System, N0, All, Kraft/PE/EVOH/PE tray with lid {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a "kraft/PE/EVOH/PE tray" and the associated elements allowing to condition a weight of 164g of dry or cured ham. 
Application to other cases: This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Cured ham" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. This inventory cannot be used to represent the same type of packaging for other products outside the sub-category "Cured ham" (PACK_AGB).

The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference), weighing of one reference and CTCPA packaging expertise.
The weighed reference is representative of the French market.

The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE).

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html .

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France. 
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Property data : ADEME

activityName: Sunflower oil, at oil mill {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
"The SALCA process ""Sunflower oil, at oil mill/kg/CH"" is used as a proxy to model Sunflower oil extraction at oil mill. 

Reference flow: Oil Yield_ (unallocated Yield_): 3.31 kg Sunflower seeds are needed for 1 kg Sunflower oil. For Sunflower at farm, the global dataset is used. Sunflower lecithin Yield_s are assumed to be about 0.3% on a seed basis (Nieuwenhuyzen (2014))

Allocation: economic allocation is applied, based on the price ratio between 1 kg oil, 2.3 kg of the co-product Sunflower oil cake and 0.01 kg sunflower lecithin. Price for 1 kg Sunflower oil = 0.72 US $/pound = 1.58 $/kg

activityName: Agaricus bisporus mushroom, fresh, at plant {NL} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of fresh agaricus bisporus mushrooms. 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the substrate production, the inoculation with mycellium, the growing chambers disinfection, soil covering (peat), the chambers temperature and humidity control (water and energy consumption) and the growing producess (water and pesticides). The direct emissions from peat are included. 
The infrastructure are excluded as well as the mushroom packaging. The spent substrate is considered to be used in agricultural systems (cut-off). 

Geography: the Netherlands. The main reference used is for Spain but the dataset is adapted to a production in the Netherlands changing the electricity mix and water regionalization. 

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2010-2014

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

Leiva 2015a: Leiva FJ, Saenz-Díez JC, Martínez E, et al (2015) Environmental impact of Agaricus bisporus cultivation process. Eur J Agron 71:141148 . doi: 10.1016/j.eja.2015.09.013
Leiva 2015c: Leival FJ, Blanco-Fernández J, Martínez-Camara E, et al (2015) Mushroom cultivation process, agaricus bisporus variety: comparison between traditional and climate controlled cultivation and identification of environmental impacts of the production processes. 3rd Int Work Simul Energy, Sustain Dev Environ SESDE 2015 4650
Leiva 2016: Leiva FJ, Saenz-Díez JC, Martínez E, et al (2016) Environmental impact of mushroom compost production. J Sci Food Agric 96:39833990 . doi: 10.1002/jsfa.7587
DAFM 2012: DAFM (2012) Pesticide Usage in Ireland, Mushroom crops survey, report 2011, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Pesticide Control Division, downloaded on http://www.pcs.agriculture.gov.ie/media/pesticides/content/sud/pesticidestatistics/Pesticde%20Usage%20-%202011%20Mushroom%20Survey%20Report.pdf in August 2018
Potocnik 2015: Potocnik I, Stepanovic M, Rekanovic E, et al (2015) Disease control by chemical and biological fungicides in cultivated mushrooms: Button mushroom, oyster mushroom and shiitake. Pestic i fitomedicina 30:201208 . doi: 10.2298/PIF1504201P
Robinson 2018: Robinson B, Winans K, Kendall A, et al (2018) A life cycle assessment of Agaricus bisporus mushroom production in the USA. Int J Life Cycle Assess 112 . doi: 10.1007/s11367-018-1456-6

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Translated name: Sugar beet, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)
Included processes: The inventory includes the process total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg sugar beets. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2006-2010, which is 93 t/ha, produced under irrigated conditions (total water use 184 m3/ha).  The data are representative for sugar beet production in France (average values) used for the export market.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.8 (i.e. very good quality)

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau

activityName: Cooking aids for bakery, 66g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Cardboard {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,5; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Propriété : ADEME

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
"Included processes: This process covers the production of dried pasta from durum wheat. The inventory includes the inputs of durum wheat semolina, energy, water and land occupied by the factory. Transport of durum wheat semolina to the factory is included. Wastes (losses) composting is considered (empty ""dummy"" dataset for composting because of the cut-off allocation method). Packaging is not included.

Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of durum wheat pasta, unpacked. The production system is based on an Italian factory producing 365'000 tonnes pasta/year. 

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)
"

activityName: Fava bean {CA-AB}| fava bean production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried fava bean (<16% moisture) during May-August, 2020, at 2089.05 ha faba bean farms located in the Province of Alberta, Canada. Yield values were averaged over 2018-2020, and farms have an average yield of 4598.52 kg grain (<16% moisture) per ha for these crop cycles. The system boundaries include the production of all crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel) and consider nitrogen credits derived from biological N fixation associated with dried faba bean production. Irrigation is included. The sowing date for the crop is May 2020 and the harvesting date is August 2020. The seeding rate is 55.35 kg/tonne of faba bean production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 1.40 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 2.46 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 0.90 kg/tonne, and sulfur (as S) 0.31 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of glyphosate 0.066 kg/tonne, bentazon 0.064 kg/tonne, and diquat dibromide 0.048 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage, seeding, fertilizer application, rolling, herbicide application, fungicide application, harvest aid application, harvesting, and other with total fuel consumption of 7.12 kg/tonne.

Production volume: 9606569.08304765 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and the sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with faba bean drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. This takes place in August, 19 weeks after the activity start. The activity includes the infrastructures and use of agricultural machinery.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Alberta
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of faba bean includes farm practices from tillage, seeding, fertilizer application, rolling, herbicide application, fungicide application, harvest aid application, harvesting, and other field operations, to aeration and drying.
Start date: 01/01/2020
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: May 2020; Harvesting date for the main crop: August 2020. Total time from the date of sowing to the date of harvesting comes to 19 weeks. Yield data were collected and averaged for three crop cycles (2018-2020). All other data were collected for 2020 only.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Apricot, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
This dataset represents the global average for Apricot, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - France: 19%
 - Spain: 11%
 - Turkey: 10%
 - Italy: 9%
These countries together represent 49% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Apricot.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality)

activityName: Mango, conventional, Val de San Francisco, at orchard {BR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Translated name: Mangue, conventionnelle, Val de San Francisco, Brésil, sortie verger
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory corresponds to the life cyle of the orchard.
Cut-off rule/Exclusion: The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest (storing) as well as all hand-works if any (e.g. pruning).
 - product declaration.
Refers to 1 kg of mango, conventional production.
ILCD - Overall data quality:
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%

Completeness (C) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%

Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%
Final note = 3 (i.e.: basic quality).
Yield: 624740 kg/ha for 25 production years (i.e. average Yield_ of 24990 kg/ha/yr).
Coproducts: None.
Allocation: None.

Dataset was generated by MEANS-InOut software. Models used : [CO2 Urea - IPCC 2006, tier 1; Inputs transportation : tropics (ecoinvent v3); Water  take off; Land occupation - ecoinvent v2; N2O Indirect - IPCC 2006, tier 1, Energy, in biomass - EcoInventv2, CO2 biogenic - EcoInvent2; Energy consumption; NH3 - EMEP 2016, tier 2; Phytosanitaries - EcoInvent2; NO3 - IPCC 2013, tier1; N2O Direct - IPCC 2006, tier 1; P Leaching - SALCA-P; CO2 Liming - IPCC 2006, tier 1; P Flow - SALCA-P; NO - EMEP 2009, tier 1; ]

Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)

activityName: Bell pepper {IN-UP}| bell pepper production, open field | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fresh Capsicum during September, 2015-May, 2016 at a farm located in village Bhagatpur Ratan, District Moradabad of Uttar Pradesh State in India. In this area, fields are irrigated with ground water using electric pump for surface irrigation. The farm has a yield of 3000 kg fresh matter per ha for this crop cycle. Sowing date for the crop is 12-October, 2015 and harvesting date is 14-Feburary, 2016. Mineral NP fertilizer input is 245.63-69 kg/ha. Organic fertilizer applied amounts to 60,000 kg of manure from cattle dung. Insecticide used has active ingredient as Carbofuran 450g/ha, Chlorantranilipore 60g/ha (Clothianidin used as proxy), Thiomethoxam 75g/ha, Monocrotophos 540g/ha (Dichlorvos (DDVP) used as proxy). Machinery is used only for soil cultivation with fuel consumption of 12.48 kg/ha using plough and rotary cultivator for soil tillage.   

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

Production volume: 8.189E7 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts about twelve weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in First week of September and sowing of seeds started about five weeks after soil preparation. Thereafter the crop is mature for harvesting in about 4 months.
Included activities end: The activity ends with the harvesting of the mature Capsicum from the Capsicum plant
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India, Uttar Pradesh
Technology level: Current
Technology: Cultivation of Capsicum follows conventional production standards
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: 07-September, 2015; Harvesting date main crop: 14-Feburary, 2016. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are taken as the middle date of the week or fortnight told to the data collector by the farmer. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 125 days.  The data is collected for one crop cycle. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoeditor.

Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 80-27-28 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 11.25 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in China amounts to 10% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

activityName: Kraft paper {RER}| kraft paper production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Kraft paper {RER}| kraft paper production | Cut-off, S

Kraft paper is produced from chemical pulp produced in the kraft process. Kraft paper can be used for a number of flexible packaging applications such as paper sacks, wrapping papers and paper bags. Within kraft paper, Sack kraft paper is a porous kraft paper with high elasticity and high tear resistance, designed for packaging products with high demands for strength and durability. The data was collected specifically for Sack kraft paper but are representative for all kraft paper production. The dataset represents a mix of white (bleached) and brown (unbleached) paper.

Data in this model is from a study by CEPI Eurokraft in 2020.

The dataset represents average data calculated from several European Sack kraft paper mills and the production year 2018. Although the data was collected specifically for sack kraft paper production, discussions with the technical experts at the mills reveal that the data are applicable for other flexible kraft packaging papers

The majority of the mills in the study are integrated mills, but some "semi-integrated mills" were included, Semi-integrated mills are either an integrated mill that has been split into two companies (pulp production and paper production) where the pulp producer has not participated in the study. Or a production site where one type of paper is made from virgin pulp and the other type of paper is made from market pulp.

The energy sources at an integrated pulp and paper mills consists of external and internal fuels plus electricity from the grid and internally produced electricity. External fuels can be fossil or biobased. The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Black liquor is the by-product of chemical pulping. It contains almost all of the inorganic cooking chemicals along with the lignin and other organic matter separated from the wood during pulping in the digester. The initial concentration of weak black liquor is about 15% dry solids in water. It is concentrated to firing conditions between 65% and 85% dry solids concentration. It is then burned in the "Recovery boiler". There are two purposes of burning the black liquor, one is to recover the inorganic cooking chemicals, the other is to make use of the energy in the organic portion of the black liquor. Source: Adams. T.N (editor) et al, "Kraft recovery boilers", 1997

The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), CH4 (fossil), N2O (fossil+ biogenic), CO (fossil+ biogenic), SO2, H2S, TRS, Total S, NOx, NH3, NMVOC, particles (all sizes), Pb and Hg. The listed air emissions are the most important emissions for the kraft paper production and cover all emissions at the mill, both from the cooking and recovering processes and combustion of fuels at different points at the plant.

For a more complete air emission profile for Sack kraft paper production, however, additional air emissions (beyond the ones listed above) were added for the combustion of the external fuels and internal using LCI datasets for combustion of different fuels as proxy. The air emissions were calculated based on the mix of the external and internal fuels in the study and more information about the fuel mix and the proxy are provided under "Extrapolations". No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, biological fibre slush, and tall oil. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry.

Production volume: 1990144000 kg
Included activities start: The process starts with the transports of wood and pulp to paper mill.
Included activities end: The activity includes transports to paper mill, wood handling, chemical pulping, paper production, energy production on-site and internal waste water treatment.
The activity ends with the paper leaving the factory gate.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Average of present used technology in 2018
Start date: 01/01/2018
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Statistics from CEPI Eurokraft for Sack production in Europe 2018. Production volume valid for 2018.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)

- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Others cakes, 160g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Rigid plastic, other than bottles {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Propriété : ADEME

activityName: Cauliflower {GLO}| cauliflower production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents  cauliflower production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 22 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 3 months.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 1.81747E10 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 1 month and it's use of electricity.  
And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included.  The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated Production
Start date: 01/01/2010
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage.

And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production.The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%).Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included.  

The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.81 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in India amounts to 30% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6338124800 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.

Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production

activityName: Maize grain, non-irrigated, at farm {BR} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: This multi-output process covers the production of maize grain and maize stover. The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of maize grain. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2017 (4.295 t/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions, with 6607 kg of maize stover produced as co-product.
 
Allocation: Based on economic allocation: maize grain (95%) and maize stover (5%).
 
System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included.
 
Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7, Very good quality

Geography: Brazil
 
Technology: Conventional production
 
Time: 2010 - 2017
 
Data sources:
- FAO. 2017. Global database of GHG emissions related to feed crops: Methodology. Version 1. Livestock Environmental Assessment and Performance Partnership (LEAP). FAO, Rome, Italy.
- Whitman, T., Yanni, S., & Whalen, J. (2011). Life cycle assessment of corn stover production for cellulosic ethanol in Quebec. Canadian Journal of Soil Science, 91(6), 9971012. https://doi.org/10.4141/cjss2011-011

activityName: Banana {RoW}| banana production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Banana {RoW}| banana production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 3.933e+10 kg

IN: PV = 2.780e+10 kg; weight = 0.7069

EC: PV = 7.502e+9 kg; weight = 0.1908

CR: PV = 2.019e+9 kg; weight = 0.05134

CO: PV = 2.005e+9 kg; weight = 0.05098

Yield of the global dataset = 36502.128103 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of banana, at standard water content (78.1%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012: Yield_ (35.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 13705 m3/ha). The data are representative for banana production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 57-0-146 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 1.84 m3/ha of liquid manure and 2.48 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 4.2 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of bananas produced in India amounts to 0.4% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing banana produced in India for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.5 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 62785376256 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period:

activityName: Biscuits, 100g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Coconut, dehusked {ID}| coconut production, dehusked | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Coconut, dehusked {ID}| coconut production, dehusked | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of coconut after manual dehusking at the farm. The co-product 'coconut husk' in included in the inventory. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012: Yield_ (6.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 2089 m3/ha). The data are representative for coconut production in Indonesia used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 45-69-30 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 1.69 m3/ha of liquid manure and 1.72 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 5.7 kg a.i./ha.

Coconut husk, is considered as a co-product of coconut production. Total coconut husk = 3.91 t/ha

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of coconut produced in Indonesia amounts to 23.6% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing coconut produced Indonesia for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 11269749760 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (60 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes limited machine operations such as fertiliser and pesticide application and irrigation. Most machine use and infrastructure are excluded as many activities (such as harvesting) are assumed to be manual work. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.

activityName: Polyethylene, high density, granulate {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polyethylene, high density, granulate {RER}| polyethylene production, high density, granulate | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial HDPE production technologies: slurry suspension polymerisation, gas phase polymerisation and solution polymerisation using Ziegler-Natta, Philips, and Metallocene catalysts.

HDPE is mainly produced with the slurry suspension, solution or the gas phase process, which belong to the low-pressure technologies. As catalysts, usually Ziegler-Natta or Phillips-type catalysts are applied, but metallocene-type catalysts can also be used. Due to this wide range of choice of process technology, reactor type, or catalyst type, a typical process for HDPE production cannot be defined.

The suspension polymerisation can be described as precipitation process. The formation of the polymer takes place in a hydrocarbon diluent and under conditions, where the monomer is soluble in the solution. The precipitated polymer, however, is insoluble and forms a fine suspension. The polymer is then separated by centrifugation. The suspension process can be combined with a stirred tank reactor or a loop reactor. Different diluents can be chosen, like C5 to C9 hydrocarbons, hexane, or isobutane.

For solution polymerisation, the hydrocarbon solvent (C9-C6) is kept at high temperature (>130 °C) to ensure that the formed polymer stays dissolved after production. In a subsequent step, the solvent is evaporated and recycled, and the liquid polymer can directly be sent to the extruder. 

In the gas phase processes a fluidised bed of polymer particles and catalyst is maintained by a steady gaseous monomer feed from the bottom of the reactor. Polymer powder is continuously extracted at the bottom of the fluidised bed reactor. Unreacted monomer gas from the top is compressed and recycled to the reactor inlet. Catalyst, and co-catalyst if necessary, is also continuously fed to the reactor. Typically Ziegler-Natta catalysts are used for gas phase polymerisation where the catalyst is supported on inert silica particles so that the reaction takes place at the catalyst surface.

After the reaction phase, most of the residual (unreacted) monomers (which are mostly present as gases) are separated from the polymer and are either recycled back into the process or flared of. Depending on the purity of the separated monomers, the gas can either be fed directly back into the production line or the monomers are returned to a purification unit. To limit the accumulation of impurities in the process, usually a small side-stream (purge) of the unreacted gas is sent back to the cracker or to a dedicated purification unit. After polymerisation, the polymer is usually fed di-rectly into a hot melt extruder, where additives can be added to the melted polymer if required. The polymer is then pelletised in an underwater pelletiser. The pelletised product is dried, blended where required and degassed.

Production volume: 6499999744 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with monomers and comonomers entering the polymerisation plant. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Coverage of production capacity in Europe: 68%

Is data valid for entire period: True

activityName: White asparagus {CN}| white asparagus production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of asparagus. The average yield from 2009 - 2012 is 5.3 t/ha. The data are representative for asparagus production in China for the export market based on average data over the country. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 80-60-40 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 0.17 m3/ha of liquid manure and 0.14 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 3.6 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of asparagus produced in China amounts to 88% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing asparagus produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6.927883E9 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing asparagus crown (seedlings).
Included activities end: This activity ends with the removal of asparagus roots after the productive phase (7 years). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the asparagus field including the establishment phase (2 years) per year of lifetime (9 years). 
The establishment phase of the asparagus field includes the nursery, manual planting, soil cultivation (plough), fertilisation (manure) and PE foil. 
The productive phase of the asparagus field includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, manual harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the asparagus roots.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of asparagus crowns (seedlings), fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for China
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Fish products, 200g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Rigid plastic, other than bottles {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Propriété : ADEME

comment:

- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1

"Included processes: This process covers the production of dried pasta from durum wheat. The inventory includes the inputs of durum wheat semolina, energy, water and land occupied by the factory. [This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Included activities start:

It also includes water use and wastewater treatment, the transformation and use of land related to the storage buildings. No process emissions were included except heat waste from the use of electricity. Packaging is not included.

activityName: Vanilla {MG}| vanilla production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Vanilla {MG}| vanilla production | Cut-off, U

This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse to represent Vanilla production in Madagascar (recommandations from CIRAD, 2022).
- no mecanisation
- lower Yield_ 
- no land use change
- negative metal emissions have been set to 0
_________________

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of vanilla. The average Yield_ from 2013 is 750 kg/ha. The data are representative for vanilla production in Madagascar used for the export market. No mineral NPK fertiliser are applied. No organic fertilisers are applied. No pesticides are applied.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of vanilla produced in the Madagascar could not be assessed within this project. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing vanilla produced in the Madagascar for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 2888000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery of vanilla plants.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of vanilla at farm gate. The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase (8 years) and transport on farm. Activities in the establishment phase (3 years) include manual planting. Activities in the productive phase include harvest of vanilla plants. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The dataset doesn't include a) irrigation, fertilisers or pesticides, because they are not applied due to extensive production where cultivation is done mainly manually b) materials for the planting, establishment and clearing phase, and c) drying because vanilla is dried at ambient temperature. Direct field emissions in this prodcution system are not caused by fertilizer or pesticide inputs from humjan activity but are related to deposition of nutrients, nutrient content of the soil and erosion.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Madagascar
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2013
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Mandarin, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Mandarin, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mulching, mowing, harvesting and irrigation. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of mandarins. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012: yield (8.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 3303 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 30 years   - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for mandarin production in China used for the export market.
Comment: Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality)

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau
Source file: ES_WFLDB_Mandarin_CN_08062015.xml

This dataset represents the cultivation of sweet sorghum on an area of 1 ha producing the co-products sweet sorghum grain and sweet sorghum stem. The Yield_ of sweet sorghum grain is 3860 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 9.1%, the Yield_ of sweet sorghum stem is 48263 kg/ha at a moisture content of 73%.

None

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 56983326720 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied. Seed input is approximated by reducing the Yield_ by 5 kg (required amount of seed per hectare for sowing)
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest and transport from field to farm (15 km). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.

activityName: Transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling {GLO}| transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling {GLO}| transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling | Cut-off, S

https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/4482b28c-ed41-487d-b331-d306ca598890 [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

This dataset represents transport of goods in lorry with atmosphere controlled (temperature, humidity, etc.) storage space set up for cooling.

While the majority of the atmosphere controlled (cold chain, refrigerated transport) road transportation is conducted with truck with semi-trailer in the cities this goods is often transported by smaller rigid trucks with refrigeration machine.

Production volume: 7853151232 tkm
Included activities start: This activity starts with input of fuel, road and vehicle infrastructure including refrigeration machine. It includes also exhaust and non-exhaust emissions.
Included activities end: This datasets combines the transport of 1 ton of goods over 1km by a lorry with refrigeration machine. The goods themselves are not included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Modern
Technology: https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/1a5c3ed8-2d10-4eae-9d60-d43536cce3ff [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

The construction of the refrigeration machine does not change very much in time. What might be changing is the 1) type of refrigerant, 2) energy consumption - efficiency and 3) leakage of the refrigerant. 

The datasets on transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine present in the ecoinvent database represent several scenarios with different type of refrigerant, energy consumption and leakage of the refrigerant.. 

The technology level is set reflecting the EURO classification, i.e. EURO3 is the oldest technology and EURO6 the newest. The R134a refrigerant is currently most widely used refrigerant, while the carbon dioxide, liquid is the newer more environmentally friendly solution. Therefore all the lorries using the carbon dioxide, liquid as refrigerant have higher level of technology than those using the R134a as refrigerant.
Start date: 01/01/2010
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Syrups, 600g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Steel {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 3; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".

'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.
