activityName: Blackberry, at farm {RS} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Blackberry at the farm, with standard water content (88.15%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 5.93 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 785 m3/ha). 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of seedling production and planting, fertilisation and pesticide application, irrigation and harvest. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (fertiliser and pesticides) are considered. Irrigation is based on blue water from Pfister for raspberries in Serbia. There is no LUC for raspberries in Serbia and the same is assumed for blackberries.  Fertilizers and manure application is mechanized while pesticides application is assumed to be done manually with manual back sprays. The harvest is assumed to be manual harvesting according to http://www.usz.gov.rs/files/publikacije/FruitIndustryInSerbia.pdf. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 15 years (Maksimovic 2014).

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

Geography: Serbia

Technology: Conventional production.

Time: 2008-2014

Data sources: 
Maksimovic 2014: Maksimovic G, Jovanovic R, Mitrovic S, Ivanovic T, 2014. Economic adequacy of blackberry production in rural areas of Sirinic district. Agroznanje, vol 15.  
Strik 2008: Strik B C, Clark J R, Finn C E, Banats M P, 2008. Worlwide production of blackberries.  Acta Hort. 777. 
http://www.usz.gov.rs/files/publikacije/FruitIndustryInSerbia.pdf

activityName: Tap water {Europe without Switzerland}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Tap water {Europe without Switzerland}| market for tap water | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'tap water', in the geography of Europe without Switzerland.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

Production volume: 478151998177280 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts from tap water, under pressure, at tap water treatment plant and fed into the tap water distribution network.
Included activities end: This activity ends with 1 kg of water at consumer (industrial or household).

This dataset includes: 
 - the distribution network
 - water losses during transmission 

This dataset doesn"t include
 - energy used during distribution for additional pressure. The tap water is already under pressure when fed into the network (see corresponding tap water production datasets). The implicit assumption is that no additional energy is required during distribution to overcome loss of load in the distribution network. This assumption is not always correct.
 - emissions to groundwater associated with water leaving the distribution network through leaks. These are assumed to be inconsequential since we are dealing with treated tap water.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe without Switzerland
Technology level: Current
Technology: 
Start date: 01/01/2012
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Polypropylene, granulate {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polypropylene, granulate {RER}| polypropylene production, granulate | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial PP production technologies: slurry suspension polymerisation,Bulk suspension polymerisation, gas phase polymerisation using Ziegler-Natta and Metallocene catalysts

PP is usually manufactured with the gas phase or the suspension (slurry) process. Modern suspension processes, however, use liquid monomers instead of a solvent and are termed bulk process.

In the gas phase processes a fluidised bed of polymer particles and catalyst is maintained by a steady gaseous monomer feed from the bottom of the reactor. Polymer powder is continuously extracted at the bottom of the fluidised bed reactor. Unreacted monomer gas from the top is compressed and recycled to the reactor inlet. Catalyst, and co-catalyst if necessary, is also continuously fed to the reactor. Typically Ziegler-Natta catalysts are used for gas phase polymerisation where the catalyst is supported on inert silica particles so that the reaction takes place at the catalyst surface.

The suspension polymerisation can be described as precipitation process. The formation of the polymer takes place in a hydrocarbon diluent and under conditions, where the monomer is soluble in the solution. The precipitated polymer, however, is insoluble and forms a fine suspension. The polymer is then separated by centrifugation. The suspension process can be combined with a stirred tank reactor or a loop reactor. Different diluents can be chosen, like C5 to C9 hydrocarbons, hexane, or isobutane.

The bulk suspension process describes the slurry suspension process used for the production of PP where the monomer propylene is used as solvent instead of other hydrocarbons. Modern suspension processes for the production of PP use liquid monomers instead of gaseous.

After the reaction phase, most of the residual (unreacted) monomers (which are mostly present as gases) are separated from the polymer and are either recycled back into the process or flared of. Depending on the purity of the separated monomers, the gas can either be fed directly back into the production line or the monomers are returned to a purification unit. To limit the accumulation of impurities in the process, usually a small side-stream (purge) of the unreacted gas is sent back to the cracker or to a dedicated purification unit. After polymerisation, the polymer is usually fed di-rectly into a hot melt extruder, where additives can be added to the melted polymer if required. The polymer is then pelletised in an underwater pelletiser. The pelletised product is dried, blended where required and degassed.

Production volume: 11000000512 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with monomers and comonomers entering the polymerisation plant. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Coverage of production capacity in Europe: 76%
Start date: 01/01/2011
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Data was collected for the year 2011, processed in 2013 and published in 2014
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Soybean {BR-RS}| soybean production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Soybean {BR-RS}| soybean production | Cut-off, U

Adaptation for Agribalyse :
- water consumption and emissions for pesticide dilution has been adapted to match Ecoinvent 3.10 correction
____________________________
The raw data collected in panels were organized in electronic spreadsheets and checked for completeness and consistency. Agricultural inputs were detailed as to their composition and physical characteristics. Agricultural operations were characterized in terms of machinery (tractor and implement), type of fuel and specific consumption. Precipitation is enought to supply water to the crop, no extra water needed. Emissions from the agricultural process were estimated using the BRCalc/ICVCalc tool, developed by Embrapa Environment, which includes specific climate and soil databases for the 137 Brazilian agricultural mesoregions, in addition to databases of parameters related to agricultural crops, fertilizers and pesticides.

The main emission models adopted by BRCalc/ICVCalc derive from the references: Nemecek et al. (2015), IPCC (2019), Nemecek & Kagi (2007). It was used the model BRLUC (Donke et al., 2020) to estimate the LUC emissions; and the PestLCI Consensus V1.0, parameterized for Brazil, to estimate pesticide emissions.

Production volume: 11294683136 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: The dataset includes the inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides. It is assumed that no organic fertiliser is applied. The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds for: limestone and gypsum application, application of plant protection product, planting with starter fertiliser, fertilising, combine harvesting and drying of grains. For other agricultural operations, the amount of fuel consumed and their emissions are estimated. The dataset also includes the transportation of products inside the farm: water, soil correctives and fertilisers from sheds to field and grain from field to truck. Furthermore, direct field emissions and land use change emissions are included, with important regionalizations added. The dataset doesn't include: seed treatment and bacterial seed inoculant (Rhyzobium sp. for nitrogen fixation from air), cleaning and storage of harvested grains. The activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Brazil, Rio Grande do Sul
Technology level: Current
Technology: This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of soybeans in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, which is composed of the soybean regions of Cachoeira do Sul, Santa Rosa and Santiago. In these regions, soybean can be produced as a monoculture or in cropping systems, including other crops such as maize and wheat. When in a cropping system, land occupation, liming operation and limestone are allocated among the products of the system, adopting factors that consider the fraction of area and the occupation time. The average productivity is 2982 kg/ha, at 13% moisture.

Agricultural operation was modelled based on the total diesel consumed to perform the operation and the emissions to air related to diesel burning.
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Time period of the most of the data collected for this dataset.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Ice lolly, 496g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 4; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".

activityName: Hazelnut, in shell, at farm {TR} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Hazelnuts in shell at the farm. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 1.27 t/ha, obtained in non-irrigated conditions. 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for planting. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included. The main data of the research were collected from 64 randomly selected, conventional hazelnut producers in the Terme district of Samsun province, Turkey, during the production period 20042005. No irrigation was considered based on a confidential source.

Data quality rating(DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

Geography: Turkey

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2008 - 2017

Data sources:
- Yield: FAOstat average over the years 2013 - 2017
- Mineral, organic fertilizers and lime: Demiryurek, K., and Cyhan, V. (2008) Economics of organic and conventional hazelnut production in the Terme district of Samsun, Turkey. Renewable Agriculture and Food Systems, pp.217 - 227. doi: 10.1017/S1742170508002251.
- Machinery fuel (diesel) and pest management: Sabzevari, A., Kouchaki-Penchah, H. and Nabavi-Pelesaraei, A. (2015). Investigation of Life Cycle Assessment of Hazelnut Production in Guilan Province of I.R. Iran Based on Orchards size Levels. Biological Forum - An International Journal, pp.807 - 813.
- Husk residue management (biowaste): Gürdil GAK, Özcan Baz Y, Demirel B, Demirel C (2016) Pelleting hazelnut husk residues for biofuel. 6th International Conference on Trends in Agricultural Engineering.

activityName: Blue cheeses - cat B, 150g | Packaging System, N0, All, Plastic tray with single lid {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
"Cat A", "Cat B, "Cat C", "Cat D", "Cat E", "Cat F", "Cat G","Cat H" : Categories specific to the types of packaging defined in the PACK_AGB report (e.g case of packaging for cheese).
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a plastic tray and the associated elements allowing to condition a total weight of 150 g of blue cheese. This specific tray is made for blue cheese (for refrigerated conservation).
This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Blue cheese" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. 

The packaging solution describes a complex PS/LDPE tray closed with a complex PET/LDPE lid.
The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference) and data collection from manufacturers. 
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg processed feedstuff (fresh weight).

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 9734000 kg
Included activities start: From reception of rye grain at the factory gate.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the production of feedstuff. The dataset includes the feedstuff processing (crushing or milling, heat treatment, dosing, mixing squeezing and pelleting), storage of the feed mixes,  water use, wastewater treatment, transformation and use of land related to the storage buildings. The dataset doesn't include process air emissions, transport of the feedstuff to the regional storehouse, solid waste generation neither packaging.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Switzerland
Technology level: Current
Technology: The values are valid for pelleted and expanded feedstuffs, and are applied to all cereals and maize. The main steps to process feedstuffs comprise of rolling, crushing or milling, heat treatment, dosing, mixing, squeezing and pelleting. The feed-milling and treatment processes were described in detail by Rossel (2001). The packaging materials are not considered in the datasets.

References

Rossel, U. (2001) Futtermüllerei: die wichtigsten Verfahren. Interner Bericht FAL Reckenholz, Zürich, 6p.

End date: 31/12/2022

activityName: Orange, fresh grade {ES}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Orange, fresh grade {ES}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of orange, fresh grade (Navelina). Fresh grade oranges are meant for direct human consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and for the year 2000: Yield_ (30 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 4187 m3/ha). The data are representative for orange production, fresh grade (Navelina), in Spain (Ribera Alta and Ribera Baixa) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 300-65-135 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 3.6 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 14 kg a.i./ha and 74.7 kg/ha of horticultural oil.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of fresh grade oranges produced in Spain amounts to 20.5% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing fresh grade oranges produced in Spain or the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 2889660672 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2000
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Time period referring to the data source: 2000-2000. Based on expert opinion data is considered to be valid at least up to 2012.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Palm fruit bunch, with deforestation, on land recently transformed, animal feed, at farm gate {MY} U
comment:
[This dataset was already contained in the AGRIBALYSE 1.3 database. It was not individually updated during the transfer to AGRIBALYSE 2.0. Therefore, the method and models used can differ from other AGRIBALYSE 2.0 productions. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the AGRIBALYSE 1.3 quality guidelines. It may have been subject to central changes described in the AGRIBALYSE change report.]

 - supporting LCI (based on the project ECOALIM).
Production of palm fruit bunch, associated with deforestation, in Malaysia. Data from Ecoinvent.
Category: Agricultural production, plant production
Product Name: Fruit de palmier a huile
Type of data: LCI, crop management sequence
Data status: restrictive
Location: MY (Malaysia)
Documentation from ecoinvent :
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
The inventory for the cultivation of oil palms GLO on recently transformed land  is modelled on the basis of data from Malaysia. Machine usage is modelled with Malaysian processings and Swiss diesel consumptions. The average annual clear-cutting of primary forest associated with the cultivation of oil palms is calculated as land tenure, arable land (the replacement of plantations is considered without any effect).  The loss/gain in carbon from mineral soils/organic soils/biomass growth is calculated as "carbon, organic, from soil or biomass stock" and released as "carbon dioxide, from soil or biomass stock". Transports are calculated with standard distances. The functional unit is 1 kg palm fruit bunches (fresh mass with a water content of 47 %). Carbon content: 0.313 kg/kg fresh mass. Biomass energy content: 16 MJ/kg fresh mass. Yield: 24978 kg/ha. The emissions of N2O and NH3 to air are calculated with standard emission factors for mineral fertilizers from Nemecek et al. 2004. The emission of nitrate to water is calculated with an estimated nitrogen loss factor of 20%.
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Production volume: 90935000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the provision of land tenure, arable land, which is provided by the clear-cutting of rainforest. This activity assumes palm fruit bunch production on a plantation with a lifetime of 20 years and represents the average operation expenditures of the production of 1 kg of fresh fruit bunch averaged across the whole lifetime including establishment, operation and clearing of the plantation. The inputs of mineral fertilisers, pesticides and irrigation water are considered. The input of seed is considered neglectable compared to the plantation lifetime of 20 years. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Most operations are done by hand. Machine operations are: fertilisation, irrigation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, transport of harvested fruit bunches from field to farm (25 km) and clearing of the plantation (wood chopping). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest and transport to the farm at the farm gate.

Geography: The inventory refers to Malaysia
Technology level: 3 Current (default)
Technology: Cultivation of oil palms.

activityName: Potato starch {GLO}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Potato starch {GLO}| market for potato starch | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'potato starch', in the Global geography.

In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.

The product 'potato starch' is a processed agricultural product with a water content of 20% by weight. The production steps include washing of the potatoes, chopping, separation of the potato fruit water, washing, refinering and finally drying of the starch.

Production volume: 4 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'potato starch',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'potato starch',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. See the complete description of AGRIBALYSE database.

Modification : ITERG


This dataset represents the production process of refined sunflower oil produced in France.  

Included processes: This process includes the partial dehulling, crushing of sunflower seeds, oil extraction by solvent and refining of crude sunflower oil. Transport of inputs are considered. System boundary is at the oil mill.
Remark: Inventory refers to the production of 1 kg refined sunflower oil, respectively 1,286 kg of sunflower oil cake, fatty acids, deodorization condensates, sunflower hulls from 2,55 kg of sunflower seeds.
Economic allocation : Economic value from AGECO report : 0,9517/kg of refined sunflower oil/ 0,1882 /kg sunflower oil cake/0,2256 /kg Sunflower fatty acids/0,2256 /kg Sunflower deodorization condensates. Economic value from AGRIBALYSE 1.4 dataset ""Sunflower hulls, low dehulling, animal feed, at transformation plant/FR U"" for Sunflower hulls : 0,08/kg. 
Geography: Data from the ACéVOL study (FNCG and ITERG, 2012), collected from French industrial sites, considered representative of national production.
Technology: Typical oil mill designed for sunflower oil solvent extraction, with pre-pressing of sunflower seeds, and refining of crude sunflower oil, French context.
Time period: Data from 2010, current technology in FR

Source : FNCG, ITERG (2012). ACéVOL - Analyse de Cycle de Vie pour les Oléagineux. Détermination de linformation environnementale des huiles de colza et de tournesol dites « de références »

Générateur : ITERG

activityName: Soft cheeses - cat G and cat I, 180g | Packaging System, N0, All, Plastic foil buche-type {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
"Cat A", "Cat B, "Cat C", "Cat D", "Cat E", "Cat F", "Cat G","Cat H" : Categories specific to the types of packaging defined in the PACK_AGB report (e.g case of packaging for cheese).
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a piece of plastic sheet used for "bà»che-type" cheeses and the associated elements allowing to condition a total weight of 180 g of soft cheese.  
This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Soft cheeses - G,I" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. 

The packaging solution describes PP foil, paper foil, and a PP reclosure label.
The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference) and data collection from manufacturers. 
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html 

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France.

based on data from IDELE "Analyse du cycle de vie du veau de boucherie : comparaison de l'efficacite environnementale de deux strategies d'alimentation" (Bénédicte de la Sayette) 2013 itself based on experts communication

Category : Agricultural production : plant production
Sub-category : Food industry : processing
Type of data : LCI

Excluded processes: the inventory doesn't take into account the infrastructure (building and machinery), transport, waste and air emissions.
Technology: the inventory is based on experts communication.
Time period: recents data
Energy values: Net Values

Pedigree matrix: 3,2,1,1,1,5

activityName: Cooked seafood, 600g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)

activityName: Tomato, medium size, conventional, soil based, non-heated greenhouse, at greenhouse {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes applied in this phase, that is the processes of irrigating, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvesting; (2) the greenhouse and the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as young plants (nursery), fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels end energy as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions in the greenhouse.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.

activityName: Red kidney bean {CA-ON}| red kidney bean production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried red kidney bean (<15% moisture) during May-September, 2020, at 1765.24 ha red kidney bean farms located in the Province of Ontario, Canada. Yield values were averaged over 2018-2020, and farms have an average yield of 2696.50 kg grain (<15% moisture) per ha for these crop cycles. The system boundaries include the production of all crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel) and consider nitrogen credits derived from biological N fixation associated with dried red kidney bean production. Irrigation is included. The sowing date for the crop is May 2020 and the harvesting date is September 2020. The seeding rate is 33.40 kg/tonne of red kidney bean production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 18.25 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 8.29 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 24.09 kg/tonne, and sulfur (as S) 2.48 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of glyphosate 0.018 kg/tonne, bentazon 0.13 kg/tonne, and prothiconazole 0.018 kg/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage, fertilizer application, pre-plant herbicide application, planting, rolling, post-emergent herbicide application, inter-row cultivating/scuffing/hilling, fungicide application, pre-harvest desiccation, pull/undercut/knife, windrow/swathing, harvesting, and other with total fuel consumption of 21.03 kg/tonne.

Production volume: 4759970.555238 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 39 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in last week of May and the sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with navy bean drying to <15% moisture at farm gate. This takes place in September, 17 weeks after the activity starts. The activity includes the infrastructures and use of agricultural machinery

Geography: The inventory is modelled for Ontario
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of red kidney bean includes farm practices from tillage, fertilizer application, pre-plant herbicide application, planting, rolling, post-emergent herbicide application, inter-row cultivating/scuffing/hilling, fungicide application, pre-harvest desiccation, pull/undercut/knife, windrow/swathing, harvesting, and other field activities, to aeration and drying.
Start date: 01/01/2020
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: May 2020; Harvesting date for the main crop: September 2020. Total time from the date of sowing to the date of harvesting comes to 17 weeks. Yield data were collected and averaged for three crop cycles (2018-2020). All other data were collected for 2020 only.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Long shelflife bread and pastries, 500g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Dairy products and desserts" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. 

The packaging solution describes the 4 PS pots with their complex lids and the grouping cardboard sheath. 
The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference), data collection from manufacturers and default data from Dairy PEFCR.
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

activityName: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 1.667e+10 kg

CN: PV = 1.590e+10 kg; weight = 0.9539

NL: PV = 5.088e+8 kg; weight = 0.03052

IL: PV = 2.599e+8 kg; weight = 0.01559

Yield of the global dataset = 35996.3522492 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the CN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of carrots. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 35 t/ha. The data are representative for carrot production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 130-40-40 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 6 m3/ha of liquid manure and 5 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 4.3 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of carrots produced in China amounts to 23% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing carrots produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 18370729984 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of the carrots and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology: 
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Chickpea {RoW}| chickpea production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fresh Chickpea during September, 2016- January, 2017 at a farm located in village Chandragadh, District Surendranagar of Gujarat. In this area, fields are irrigated using electric pump for surface irrigation. The farm has a yield of 2900 kg fresh matter per ha for this crop cycle. Sowing date for the crop is 02-October, 2016 and harvesting date is 09-January, 2017. Mineral NP fertilizer input is 77-51 kg/ha. Organic fertilizer applied amounts to 14,000 kg of compost from cattle dung. Insecticide used has active ingredient as Dimethoate 104g/ha, Chlorpyrifos 137.55g/ha, Monocrotophos 79.80g/ha. Machinery is used for soil cultivation, other work processes with fuel consumption of 72 kg/ha, and 6.40 kg/ha respectively.

Production volume: 4.91295E9 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts about three weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in third week of September and sowing of seeds started about 10 days after soil preparation. Thereafter the crop is mature for harvesting in about 3 months.


Included activities end: The activity ends with the harvesting of the mature Chickpea (gram in local language) from the Chickpea plant. Thereafter the field is prepared for cultivation of the next crop.

Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology: Cultivation of Chickpea follows conventional production standards
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: 21-September, 2016; Harvesting date main crop: 09-January, 2017. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are taken as the middle date of the week or fortnight told to the data collector by the farmer. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 100 days.  The data is collected for one crop cycle. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoeditor.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Coconut, dehusked, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of irrigation, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvest. Machine use and infrastructure are excluded as most of the work is assumed to be manual work. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and planted trees are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.

Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of coconut after manual dehusking at the farm. The co-product "Coconut husk, at farm" in included in the inventory.  The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012: yield (4.4 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 3076 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 60 years. Tree density: 175 trees/ha.   - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for coconut production in Philippines used for the export market. Economic allocation between the coconut and the husk is considered, with allocation factors from the Agri-Footprint 1.0 "Economic allocation" database (i.e. 93% to the coconut, 7% to the husk).
Technology: Conventional production.

Comment: Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for the Philippines. The original land use of 96.8 % of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. To avoid a potentially significant underestimation of land use change impacts, the conservative assumption was made that the unknown land transformation share shall be attributed to transformation from forest land (primary and secondary).

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Soybean {BR}| market for soybean | Cut-off, U

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'soybean', in the geography of Brazil.

This is dataset represents the transport of 1 kg of soybeans from the production farm to the plant producting soybean meal and soybean oil. No losses are considered in this dataset.

The product 'soybean' is a seed. It is an annual crop. The ecoinvent database also contains this product from organic and Swiss integrated production.

comment:

This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Translated name: Rapeseed, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)
Included processes: 'The inventory includes the processes of sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation, harvest and grain drying. Tillage practice in western Canada from 2005 were assumed to be representative: full tillage = 24%, conservation tillage = 26%, no tillage = 50%, although no tillage and conservation tillage are likely to be higher now than in 2005. Rapeseeed is normally not irrigated in western Canada. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of rapeseed, at standard water content required for storage (8%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012 (1.9 t/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions. Data are representative for canola production in western Canada, that represents 80% of acres in Canada, used for the export market. From the sources used it is not clear, wether data is for GMO or non-GMO canola. About 90% of canola in Canada is genetically modified (herbicide-resistance).

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.2 (i.e. excellent quality)

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 18174699520 kg

Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage.

Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

activityName: Cooking, industrial, 1kg of cooked product {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset is gate-to-gate and models the cooking process of 1 kg of food, by considering an equal-weight average of a frying process, an oven-baking process and a boiling process for 1 kg of food. For the 3 processes, the machineries have been excluded since we consider a lifetime of 10 years for the appliances, and a large batch size.
_Frying : The process includes electricity consumption and cooking oil consumption. It does not include air emissions life-cycle, by lack of data. The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
_Boiling : The process includes electricity consumption and cooking oil consumption. It does not include air emissions life-cycle, by lack of data.  The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
The process includes electricity consumption. It excludes air emission due to lack of data. The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
In the development of Agribalyse 3.0, the upstream life-cycle stages of the food product, downstream life cycle stages and packaging from gate to consumer are added separately.

_Energy consumption : The energy consumption data was found consistent with basic thermal calculations based on BREF generic data. For boiling (blanching), the energy consumption for gas boiling has been averaged between the data presented for potato blanching and the data presented for pasta boiling (Fusi et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2012). For frying, the energy consumption has been extracted from a study on potato frying as French fries (Mouron et al., 2016).
_Additional ingredients : Additional ingredients accounted for are tap water, for boiling, and rapeseed oil, for frying.
_Emissions : Emissions to air (water from boiling) and emissions to water are included for boiling process
_Waste management : or the frying process, used oil is collected separately to be purified. According to the decree on 12th July 201, the collection of used cooking oil is mandatory in order to recycle it (Legifrance, 2011). In January 2016, the obligation threshold was lowered at 60 tons per year, meaning this obligation is applicable to a large amount of food industries.  We used the ecoinvent dataset: "Used vegetable cooking oil, purified (FR) treatment of used vegetable cooking oil, purification, Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent". The geographical scope for the ecoinvent dataset is French specific and covers all the end of life process: collection, transport, effluent treatment, storage and credits for the recovered oil. Other solid wastes are out of scope (Appliances at end of life and maintenance and cleaning material).
_Transport : we used "market for" datasets already (transportation already included in these datasets). 
_

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 3; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Canning fruits or vegetables, industrial, 1kg of canned product {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset is gate-to-gate and covers all stages from peeled fruit or vegetable to canned fruit or vegetable: slicing of fruit or vegetable, can filling and sterilization. It is assumed to take place in France. Consequently, all datasets are chosen for France and Europe, when not available for France.
The figure below represents the life cycle boundaries.
The downstream stages from plant gate to consumer are out of scope, in accordance with the Agribalyse 3.0 methodology. The following stages are excluded from the system:
o The washing of fruit and vegetable prior to canning (excluded in Agribalyse 3.0 LCIs)
o The production and EoLof packaging, included elsewhere in upstream or downstream LCIs in Agribalyse v3.0

The figure represents the system modelling.

A review of bibliography has been done to collect data on canning processes, along with an interview with a French canning process expert. The expert reviewed and validated the data collected from literature. Our research on vegetables led to compiling five studies, calculating the average electricity, steam and water consumption for each step of the canning process. For fruits, we reviewed the data for peach canning, which amounted to a single study (Folinas et al., 2015). The data was considered not robust enough, leading to excluding fruit canning from the scope of the model.
_From the bibliography and the interview with a canning expert, we derived the energy consumptions for the vegetable canning process see section 8. One study provided the total energy consumption for canning (steam and electricity), it was used as a reference (Rao, 1977).  As explained previously, considering that water and steam circulates in a closed loop throughout the process, only the energy for pumping and heating water has been considered in the modelling of the water circuit.
_The canning process involves water and steam consumption. However, according to the data provided by our canning process expert, water and steam are processed within a closed loop. Thus, water consumption for steam, cooling and other processes was not included in the scope. In order to calculate the water quantity in the cans, we calculated an average among data from Openfoodfacts website (Google Play app, 2019)
_In the Cradle to Consumer Life Cycle Greenhouse Gas Accounting of Sweet Corn in Minnesota (Miller, 2017) considers the addition of 7,27 g of salt per kg of canned corn. This value has been adopted after validation by our canning expert.
_The food losses at the sub-steps of the process have not been modelled. The loss are modelled at a global process level. Therefore, a 1% default loss rate is applied at the end of the process. This is a conservative approach since all flows are augmented by 1%. The resulting waste (food, water and salt) are included in the inventory.
_Emissions are related to solid waste due to the global product loss. Consequently, 1% of input food, water and salt are treated at the end of life.
_ Transportation is not modelled in the inventory, as it is already accounted for in the electricity and salt inventories. The electricity inventory is an ecoinvent "market" inventory accounting for electricity transportation, and the salt Acyvia inventory relies on an ecoinvent sodium chloride "market" inventory.
_ The packaging life cycle is not included. The future practitioner will be in charge of adding the appropriate packaging manufacture and end of life, as well as the 1% loss rate related to the canning process.

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.
