Cow milk {RoW}| milk production, from cow | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset was built as a weighted average of regional datasets of the same activityName.  Weights are based on production volumes.

ZA: production volume = 3.15e+09 kg/year, weight = 0.5116

CA-QC: production volume = 3.01e+09 kg/year, weight = 0.4884

Production volume: 5.96413862488E11 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts from the reception and storage of feed materials, and dairy herd housing.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the provision of milk at farm, ready-to-deliver. The dataset includes the consumption of feed; the livestock management operations (including bedding, drinking water, milking equipment, cleaning products and water, ammonia and dinitrogen oxyde emissions from housing, and methane emissions from enteric fermentation), manure management emissions; energy and buildings (including electricity for dairying, cattle housing and milk parlour equipment and buildings, and gasoline for regular operations) necessary for the operation of a typical dairy farm. The dataset does not include fodder and feed production and processing into meal for animals, litter production, manure management operations (however, emissions are accounted for); nor milk transportation beyond the farm gate (e.g. to dairy processing plants). Also, the dataset does not include particulate matter emissions, nor any drugs used on the dairy farm, because of the lack of data available on quantities and content. In terms of mass, drugs represent much less than 1% of inputs.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. See the complete description of AGRIBALYSE database.

Modification: ITERG

Data are representative of refined soybean oil production from soybean seeds. 5,4k g of soybean seeds are needed to produce 1 kg of refined soybean oil and 4,24 kg of soybean oil cake. 
Data source : industrial data, representative for crushing and refining of soybean oil in Europe. Data from FEDIOL, 2013. Life cycle assessment of EU Oilseed Crushing and Vegetable oil refining. Final report 59 pages
Economic Allocation
Economic value from FEDIOL report : 0,809/kg of refined soybean oil, 0,297/kg of soybean oil meal, 0,6/kg of soybean lecithin, 0,35/kg of soybean soap stock

The consumption mix of soybean oil in France was determined with importation and production data from FAOSTAT (average 2015-2019). The average consumption mix (2015-2019) was : France, 70%, Spain, 12%, others origins (mainly UE countries)  : 18%. Only French origin are considered in this dataset, representing 70% of market mix

activityName: Rye grain {GLO}| market for rye grain | Cut-off, U
comment:
This process is no longer part of the ecoinvent 3 database and will not be updated. Please, choose another process.

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'rye grain', in the Global geography.

In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.

The product 'rye grain' is a grain. It is an annual crop. The ecoinvent database also contains this product from organic and Swiss integrated production.

Production volume: 15152620544 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'rye grain',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'rye grain',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

The data was produced from collection from manufacturer. Average weights were calculated to be representative of supermarket references.

The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

activityName: Rapeseed, conventional, 9% moisture, national average, animal feed, at farm gate, production {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of rapeseed  (9% moisture), conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements.

Coffee (grounded), 250g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 2,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 5; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Salts, 125g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Cardboard {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
This dataset represents the global average for banana, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Ecuador: 29.5%
 - Costa Rica: 10.5%
 - Colombia: 9.7%
 - India: 0.4%
These countries together represent 50% of global export.
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of banana.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality)

activityName: Asparagus, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Asparagus, at farm
Included processes: The inventory includes all activites of an average year in the productive phase of an asparagus field, i.e. soil cultivation, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvesting (manually). Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation water and seedlings are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered. Also regarded are the first two years of the non-productive phase, i.e.planting (manually), soil cultivation (plough), fertilisation (manure) and PE foil.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of asparagus. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012 (i.e. 5.3 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (4089 m3/ha total amount water). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded. Included are also the two non-productive years. Asparagus has a lifetime of 9 years and 7 years in the productive phase. The data are representative for asparagus production in China based on average data over the country.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality)

activityName: Raw cow milk archetype, feed mix IT-154, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Dairy farm archetype IT-154 according to FAO, IDF, IFCN (2014).
IT-154 represents an average-sized farm in northern Italy (Lombardy), having Holstein cows with a milk yield of 8 810 kg milk/cow per year. The cows are kept in a free stall barn where milking is done in a parlour system. The farm operates on 72 ha of land that is very fertile and can also be used for cash crops. About 56 percent of the work on the farm is done by family members.

Allocation between milk and meat (live animals) based on bio-physical causality (IDF 2015)
Inventory is for 1 kg raw milk, uncorrected. Mass produced is given for FPCM equivalent (IDF 2015)
Co-product is beef cattle, from dairy farm (culled cows and male calves).

Included: all feed inputs, pasture and pasture-related emissions, enteric emissions.
Excluded: milking, farm infrastructure and energy/water consumption, manure management, packaging, transport for raw milk collection.

Hence the raw milk archetypes datasets are intended to be used in the raw milk national mix datasets, where manure management, farm processes and local peat degradation are also combined. The inventory is presented for 1 kg uncorrected raw milk, but the output quantity is corrected to correspond to 1 kg of FPCM.

1 kg FPCM (fat and protein corrected milk)
1 kg LW (live weight) beef cattle, from dairy farm
Milk yield = 8810 kg year-1 cow-1
Number of dairy cows per farm = 154
Number of heifers per farm = 118 (avg)

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 ( i.e. very good quality)

activityName: Sweet corn, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
This dataset represents the global average for Sweet corn, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Thailand: 25%
 - Hungary: 21%
 - United States: 17%
These countries together represent 63% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Sweet corn.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality)

activityName: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.329e+8 kg

CA: PV = 5.526e+8 kg; weight = 0.6635

RU: PV = 2.803e+8 kg; weight = 0.3365

The comments below were part of the CA regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of linseed grains. The average Yield_ from 2003-2004 is 1.3 t/ha at standard water content required for storage (10%). The data are representative for linseed production in western Canada used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-10-0 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 4 m3/ha of liquid manure and 3 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 1.69 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of linseed grains produced in Canada amounts to 59% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing linseed grains produced in Canada for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1231968256 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of grains at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production and b) drying due to lack of data.

activityName: Tea rehydrated with water at consumer step, 30g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Cardboard {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Peach, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Peach, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mulching, mowing, harvesting and irrigation. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of peach. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009-2012: yield (15 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (water use for irrigation 7058 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 19 years   - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for peach production in China used for the export market.
Comment: Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality).

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau
Source file: ES_WFLDB_PeachCN_22062015.xml

Translated name: Sunflower, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of soil tillage, sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvest. Drying is not applied systematically (assumption 10% of Yield_ is dried). Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of sunflower grains, at standard water content required for storage (9%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2006 - 2010, which is 2.4 t/ha with an average irrigation of 24 m3 water/ha (4% of the sunflower fields are irrigated irrigated, receiving 600 m3/ha water).  The data are representative for conventional sunflower seed production in France, considering an average of irrigated and non-irrigated fields, used for the export market.

_________________________________
Reference flow: This multi-output process covers the production of barley grain and barley straw. The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of barley grain. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2017 (5.78 t/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions, with 3984 kg of barley straw produced as co-product.
 
Allocation: Based on economic allocation: barley grain (75.6%) and barley straw (24.4%).

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included.
 
Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7, Very good quality

Geography: Germany
 
Technology: Conventional production
 
Time: 2010 - 2017
 
Data sources:
- FAO. 2017. Global database of GHG emissions related to feed crops: Methodology. Version 1. Livestock Environmental Assessment and Performance Partnership (LEAP). FAO, Rome, Italy.
- FEFAC. 2015. PEF screening report in the context of the EU Product Environmental Footprint Category Rules (PEFCR) Pilots  Feed for food producing animals. Draft version 2.0 for EF Steering Committee. European Feed Manufacturers' Federation. October 2015

activityName: Condiment sauces, 250g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Glass {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. activityName: Olive {ES}| olive production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of olives. The average yield from 2009 - 2012 is 5 t/ha. The data are representative for olive production in Spain (Andalusia) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-60 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 2.15 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of olives produced in Spain amounts to 37% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing olives produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.5 (i.e. excellent quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6.45975425E9 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (40 years, 250 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

System boudaries: cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of tree seedling production and planting, fertilizer and pesticide, irrigation and harvest. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change (LUC) are considered. The irrigation is based on blue water from Pfister for fruit nes and the LUC consider fruit fresh nes for Poland as proxy for elderberry. The harvest is assumed to be done by hand. Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.8, Very good quality

Geography: Poland

Technology: Conventional production.

Time: 2014-2015

_____________________________________________________________________________

This dataset represents green bell pepper production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 80 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 6 months.

Greenhouse production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). 
Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Tomato, fresh grade {ES}| tomato production, fresh grade, in unheated greenhouse | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Tomato, fresh grade {ES}| tomato production, fresh grade, in unheated greenhouse | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of loose classic tomato for fresh consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2006 - 2009: Yield_ (165 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 4748 m3/ha). The data are representative of loose classic tomatoes for fresh consumption, produced in Spain (Almeria) for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 798-506-1562 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 32.3 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of fresh grade tomatoes produced in Spain amounts to 10.4 % of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing fresh grade tomatoes produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 4255320576 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and transport to the farm gate. Storage is not included. 
The dataset includes all activities during a cycle, i.e. all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations include: soil cultivation, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Irrigation is included, as well as greenhouses infrastructures and energy consumption when relevant. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2006
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Time period referring to the data source: 2006-2009. Based on expert opinion data is considered to be valid at least up to 2012.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Baby deserts, 250g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Rigid plastic, other than bottles {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Propriété : ADEME

activityName: Sweet corn {US-MN}| sweet corn production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Sweet Corn (fresh matter) in the US state of Minnesota at farm, with an at harvest moisture content of 76.%. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. Residues are not collected but remain on the field post-harvest and overwinter.

The average yield of Sweet Corn grown in Minnesota for the 2014-2021 seasons was 16,813 kg/ha (wet mass) (USDA NASS (2022a)).  The dataset reflects the average Sweet Corn produced in Minnesota from 2014 to 2021, inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices (0% no till, 0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage) (EPA 2022; IPM center 2003; IPM center 1997 data) and being grown in rotations with other vegetable crops. While genetically engineered sweet (fresh) corn seed is available, the share of sweet (fresh) corn grown from genetically engineered seed is not compiled; it is estimated that between 75 and 90% of North American sweet corn is conventional (USDA 2018b).

Area, productivity, use of mineral and organic fertilisers and pesticides, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture where possible or budgets available for the state, unless otherwise noted. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA.  57.6% of crop land has installed drainage (tile or ditch), based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA.  Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (13.5% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018d)).

Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Minnesota increased by 1% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020); USDA NASS does not report cropped area for Sweet Corn prior to 2016.

Soil characteristics, including pH, are based on distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.

References:

USDA NASS (2022a) Area, Production, Yield by State - Sweet Corn - 2016-2022. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC)

USDA NASS (2018b) Statistical Methodology Name of Survey: Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Phase II: PeanutProduction Practices Report, CornProduction Practices Report, and Soybean Production Practices Cost Report. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Surveys/Guide_to_NASS_Surveys/Chemical_Use/2018_Peanuts_Soybeans_Corn/Statistical%20Methodology%202018.pdf

IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/MDcorn-sweet.pdf

IPM center (2003) Crop Profile for Sweet Corn in the North Central United States. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center.Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/us-ncr-sweetcorn.pdf

Synonym:
Zea mays L., corn
Production volume: 708507.502003583 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. It ends with harvested sweet corn at the farm gate, prior to storage.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for United States of America, Minnesota
Technology level: Current
Technology: This dataset reflects current practice for Sweet Corn in Minnesota as of 2022.
Start date: 01/01/2014
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: The valid period covers 2014-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources. The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 2 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing  impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on enterprise crop budgets and other guidance and change little year to year. State specific guidance for Minnessota is not available. Field operations are assumed as Wisconsin.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Fish dishes, frozen, 400g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Pop corn, 100g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Plastic film {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Orange, fresh grade {ZA}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Orange, fresh grade {ZA}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of orange, fresh grade. Fresh grade oranges are meant for direct human consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year in 2015: Yield_ (38.11 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions. The data are representative for orange production, fresh grade, in South Africa used for the export market.

None

None

Production volume: 1645182976 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard. The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (33 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, and irrigation. Direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (N-P2O5- K2O from mineral fertiliser input: 143-35-64 kg/ha*a ) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for South Africa
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: False
Time period: This dataset is based on data from the 2015 production year according to CGA Key Industry Ststostics and approved Confronting Climate Change datasets.

activityName: Olive, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Olive, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mulching, mowing, harvesting and irrigation. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase. 
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of olives. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2001-2008: yield (4.3 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (water use for irrigation 300 m3/ha; only 20% irrigated). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 40 years - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for Olive production in Italy (Puglia region or Sicily) used for the export market.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.5 (i.e. excellent quality)

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau
Source file: ES_WFLDB_Olive_IT_08062015.xml

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Coffee, green bean {IN}| coffee green bean production, arabica | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Coffee, green bean {IN}| coffee green bean production, arabica | Cut-off, U
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of green coffee beans (Arabica). Arabica is a variety of coffee that has a sweeter, softer taste, with tones of sugar, fruit, and berries. It has a higher acidity but twice less caffeine compared to Robusta beans, and is generally considered to be of higher quality compared to Robusta. Arabica is mostly grown in Latin America and India. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2012 - 2014: Yield_ (725 kg/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 352 m3/ha). The data are representative for Arabica green coffee beans production in India (Karnataka state) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 900-0-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.15 kg a.i./ha and 3.7 kg/ha of neem oil.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of coffee produced in India amounts to 3.4% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing Arabica green coffee beans produced in India for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 91972128 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Green coffee beans are sun-dried.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2012
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Tea, dried {CN}| tea production, dried | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of tea. The average yield from 2009 - 2012 is 1.1 t/ha. The data are representative for tea production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 35-10-10 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 10.63 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of tea produced in China amounts to 15% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing tea produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 3.2 (i.e. fair quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1.572053E9 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), and the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: fertiliser and pesticide application, and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
   Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of pear. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 48.2 t/ha. The data are representative for pear production in Belgium used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 36-0-21 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 2.56 m3/ha of liquid manure and 1.71 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 26.15 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of pear produced in Belgium amounts to 12% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing pear produced in Belgium for the export market.

The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (21 years, 2357 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.
