activityName: Lentil {CA-SK}| lentil production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2 in the original Ecoinvent LCI :
- Replacement of the negativ emission in the original LCI by 0
- Replacement of the transormation land use flow unspecified by the annual crop non-irrigated

This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried lentil product with a dry matter content of 84% at minimum  during May-August, 2019, at 84924.57 ha lentil farms located in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada. Farms have Yield_ of 1701.66 kg dried matter per ha for this crop cycle. The system boundaries include the production of all of crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel). There is an estimated 0.49 kg of N fixation per tonne of lentils produced in this region that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. Irrigation is not included since it is rarely performed for lentils in this region. Sowing date for the crop is May, 2019 and harvesting date is August, 2020. Seeding rate is 0.06 kg/tonne of lentil production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 5.19 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 18.12 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 1.77 kg/tonne, sulfur (as S) 2.66 kg/tonne, and zinc (as Zn) 0.05 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of Glyphosate 642.36 g/tonne, Ethalfluralin 76.88 g/tonne, and Sethoxydim 34.00 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, and burndown/desiccant application with total fuel consumption of 51.60 kg/tonne.

None

Production volume: 144758.796875 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with lentil drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. Carbon and nitrogen emissions associated with above- and below-ground biomass are accounted for using the DNDC model. This model was also used to calculate a nitrogen fixation credit that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. For lentils in this region, the N credit was estimated to be 0.49 kg/t.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Saskatchewan
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of lentil includes farm practices from tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, burndown/desiccant application, to drying.
Start date: 01/01/2017
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: April - May 2019; Harvesting date main crop: August, 2017-2019. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are the data collected by the farmers. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 119 days. The data is collected for three crop cycles. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoinvent.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Sodium chloride, powder {GLO}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Sodium chloride, powder {GLO}| market for sodium chloride, powder | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'sodium chloride, powder', in the Global geography.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

'sodium chloride, powder'  is an inorganic substance with a CAS no. : 007647-14-5. It is called 'sodium chloride' under IUPAC naming and its molecular formula is: NaCl. It is solid under normal conditions of temperature and pressure and appears as a white crystalline solid. It is modelled as a pure substance.  On a consumer level, is used in the following products: cosmetics and personal care products, fertilisers, anti-freeze products, perfumes and fragrances and water treatment chemicals. On industrial sites, the substance is used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: formulation of mixtures and/or re-packaging, textile, leather or fur, pulp, paper and paper products, chemicals, mineral products (e.g. plasters, cement) and electrical, electronic and optical equipment.

Production volume: 3481869824 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'sodium chloride, powder',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'sodium chloride, powder',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Celery {GLO}| celery675 production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents celery production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 40 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 5.75 months.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 8969982976 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 7 months and it's use of electricity.  And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production. 
The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current

activityName: Lentils, dry, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of dry lentils at farm (moisture content 14%). The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year (1710 kg/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions. The dataset represents a mix of red and green lentils with a ratio of 75/25 red/green based on registered sales rates.

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included. After harvesting, lentils are transferred to a storage bin close to the farm, where they are mechanically dried by aeriation to maintain safe storage. Lentil straw has no economic value, and is not harvested, therefore no co-product or residue treatment is accounted for.

Data quality rating: 1.2 (i.e. excellent quality)

Geography: The dataset describes the production of lentils in Saskatchewan and Alberta provinces in Canada

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2012-2017

Data sources:
1. (S&T)2 Consultants (2017) Carbon Footprint for Canadian lentils. Canadian Roundtable on Sustainable Crops
2. ttps://albertapulse.com/lentil-harvesting/

- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Ware potato, conventional, for industrial use, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of ware potato for industrial use, 80% moisture, conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).
PEF  Overall data quality :

Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2 : Good
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 3 : Fair
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 2 : Good
Final note = 2,25 : Good data quality level
Yield: 44700.0 kg
Coproducts: None.. Allocation: None.. 
undefined

activityName: Avocado {GLO}| avocado production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents avocado production.

Yield: 10 t / ha. 

Duration of one cycle: 12 months in permanent culture

Field production. 

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 3.840905E9 kg
Included activities start: From maintenance of the orchards after harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.9 month and it's use of electricity. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. 
The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production without production standard, but according to GAP
Start date: 01/01/2010
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Mustard, proxy from Rape seed {Canada without Quebec}| rape seed production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rape seed {Canada without Quebec}| rape seed production | Cut-off, U

Adaptation in AGB 3.3 to be a better proxy for mustard (the main proportion of the mustard seeds comes from canada, and rape seed and mustard is quiet similar in term of cultures): 
- mustard culture is not a GMO and most of the time the herbicide is not glufosinate, the replacement of "glufosinate" by "pesticide unspecified" has been done (as input of the technosphere and emission to soil)

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of rapeseed, at standard water content required for storage (8%). The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1.9 t/ha. Data are representative for rapeseed production in western Canada, that represents 80% of fields in Canada, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 85-20-0 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 3.27 m3/ha of liquid manure and 2.33 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 1.03 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of rapeseed produced in Canada amounts to 44% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing rapeseed produced in Canada for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.3 (i.e. excellent quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 13809125376 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of grains and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation (a mixture of no tillage and minimum tillage), sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, grain drying, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production and b) irrigation because rapeseed is normally not irrigated in western Canada.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Canada without Quebec
Technology level: Current

activityName: Chocolate spread, 350g | Packaging System, Proxy Pack, Glass {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

Functional unit: 1kg of packaged food product

The packaging solutions mentioned as PROXY PACK have been developed with a simplified approach but are based on datasets from PACK-AGB project. These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

Générateurs : CTCPA
Vérificateurs : CTCPA (packaging expert from CTCPA)
Contact : Pauline AUDOYE (paudoye@ctcpa.org) ; Mathilde BRAMBATI (mbrambati@ctcpa.org) ; Margaux COLOMBIN(mcolombin@ctcpa.org)
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Propriété : ADEME

activityName: Corrugated board box {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Corrugated board box {RER}| corrugated board box production | Cut-off, S

Corrugated Board is manufactured from several specially conditioned layers of recycled or virgin papers, with the Fluting Medium being the middle layer and Linerboard used for the outside layers. Reels of Fluting Medium and Linerboard are fed into a machine which is called a Corrugator (FEFCO, 2018). In integrated plants such as the ones represented here, the finished board is further folded into boxes.

https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/fb7c96f2-1933-4a81-a33a-515d0a5fb151 [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

The data on corrugated board production are based on 389 plants (mostly integrated plants with corrugated board and box production on the same site) in Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the United Kingdom. Together they produced 12,100,000 tonnes saleable product, which is 54% of the total annual production of corrugated board products in Europe. Each of the production sites produces on average 31.100 tonnes of corrugated sheets, ranging from 5.000  500.000 tonnes each. Reference(s): https://www.fefco.org/sites/default/files/documents/LCA%20Report%202019_revised_%20p%2037.pdf, accessed September 2022.

For this dataset the European average of recycled and virgin paper inputs (wellenstoff, semichemical fluting, kraftliner, testliner) was used.

The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil), CO, NOx (as NO2), SOx (as SO2), particulates (all sizes).

For a more complete air emission profile, additional air emissions (beyond the ones listed above) were added for the combustion of the external fuels and internal using LCI datasets for combustion of different fuels as proxy. The air emissions were calculated based on the mix of the external fuels in the study and more information about the fuel mix and the proxy are provided under "Extrapolations".

The production volume is valid for the year 2018. Inventory data were collected for the year 2018.

Production volume: 24306999296 kg
Included activities start: The process starts as reels of Fluting Medium and Linerboard are fed into a machine called a Corrugator.
Included activities end: This activity ends with folded corrugated board boxes ready for delivery.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Average of present used technology

The Fluting Medium paper is conditioned with heat and steam and fed between large corrugating rolls that give the paper its fluted shape in the Single Facer. Starch is applied to the tips of the flutes on one side and the inner liner is glued to the fluting. The corrugated fluting medium with liner attached to it is called single face web and travels along the machine towards the Double Backer where the single face web meets the outer liner and forms corrugated board. A number of layers of single faced web may be built up to produce double and triple wall corrugated board. The corrugated board is slit into the required widths and cut into sheets which are then stacked or palletised. The final stage of the process consists of printing and then slotting, folding and gluing the corrugated board to manufacture a corrugated box.
Start date: 01/01/2018
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

_________________________________
This dataset represents the global average for Sunflower, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Hungary: 18%
 - France: 11%
 - Ukraine: 8%
 - Russia: 0.26%
These countries together represent 40% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Sunflower, at standard water content required for storage of 10%.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.3 (i.e. good quality)

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

The inventory includes : (1) only the main packaging material (in contact with the product) ; (2) the transport for packaging supply (ratio FR and ratio RER) ; (3) only the main process ; (4) the end of life of the main packaging material.

These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Soybean grain dried, stored and transported, processing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. - supporting LCI (based on the project ECOALIM).
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of crop cultivation, transport of fresh matter from farm to storage (9 km by tractor, 35 km by truck), storage, and drying when necessary.
Remark: Generic data for all types of French crop are used for transport, based on Arvalis-Institut du Végétal expertise. Drying, when necessary, is expressed as quantity of liters discharged from the grain. This quantity is calculated based on initial moisture and required final moisture.

activityName: Silage maize, conventional, national average, animal feed, at farm gate, production {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of dry matter of silage maize, conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.6 month and it's use of electricity.  And for the production, mulch films are included and disposed according to the disposal techniques used in the production country. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

These datasets have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This process describes the production of 57506 kg of Pineapple, at farm/TH U
This dataset has been adapted from the WFLDB dataset ""Pineapple, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)/CR U"". Ratio Yield_ Costa Rica to Kenya is 2,40 (Yield in Thaïland : 35813kg/ha), thus the occupation, annual crop has been adapted with the Yield_ ratio. Field operations are linked to the work rate expressed in hours/hectare. As the Yield_ is lower in Kenya, the operations are on larger surfaces: adaptation of the diesel consumed and of the land use change by multiplying by the ratio.

activityName: Pomegranate {RoW}| pomegranate production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fresh Pomegranate which is a peripheral crop harvested in May, 2016 at a farm located in village- Vadner Bhairav  and District- Nashik of Maharashtra. The farm has a yield of 60,000 kg fresh matter per ha for this crop cycle. Harvesting date is 15-May, 2016. Mineral NPK fertilizer input is 54.68-89.69-166.25 kg/ha. Micro/macro nutrients applied are Mg 135.47 kg/ha, Zinc 54.26 kg/ha, Borax 51.67, Manganese sulfate 27.13 kg/ha, Portafer 72.34 kg/ha, and Sulfite 103.62 kg/ha. Organic fertilizer applied amounts to 9000 kg of manure from Local mix slurry. Fungicides used has active ingredient as Carbendazin 750g/ha, Mancozeb 6187.5g/ha. Insecticides used has active ingredient as Dimethoate 900g/ha, Dichlorovos 2280g/ha, Chlorpyriphos 450g/ha, Imidacloprid 267g/ha. Other pesticide used is plant based horticultural oil (neem and Karanj) 15.19 kg/ha. Machinery is used for Pesticide spray with fuel consumption of 6.24 kg/ha and for Nutrient spray with fuel consumption of 18.72 kg/ha. 

Production volume: 6.9355E8 kg
Included activities start: This is a perennial crop with periodic harvesting

Included activities end: The activity ends with the harvesting of the mature Pomegranate from the tree.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:  Cultivation of Pomegranate follows conventional production standards
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Harvesting date main crop: 15-May, 2016. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoeditor.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Honey, raw, small-scale production, unpackaged, at farm {CH} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of raw honey, un-packaged. The reference flow is the average honey Yield_ per colony and per year, from 2007  2017 (10 kg/colony/year) based on primary data collected from a typical small-scale Swiss honey producer (40 colonies).

Allocation: Potential co-products from raw honey production are beewax, nucs, pollen and fruit tree pollination. The entire beekeeping activity is allocated to raw honey production.

System boundaries: Cradle-to-farm. The inventory includes wood for the bee hive infrastructure, inputs for bee feeding and varroa destructor management (natural chemical treatment), commuting of the beekeeper to the bee hives and honey extraction at the production site. Hive protective paints/varnishes, pollination activities, extracting equipment, packaging and transportation of raw honey to the raw honey consumer/retailer or to the raw honey processing place are not included. No co-product is included within the dataset.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.2, Excellent quality

Geography: Switzerland

Technology: Conventional small-scale production

Time: 2007  2017

Data sources:
- Primary data. Small-scale Swiss honey producer (Association MELLIFERA, 2018. Personal communication)

Literature reference
Methodological Guidelines for the Life Cycle Inventory of Agricultural Products.

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1

Time period: Inventory data based on 2023 " Plein Pot Sur les Emballages " (PPSE) data (data from ADEME and Open Food Facts)

Use of "PPSE" data to improve packaging modelling for products not covered by the "PACK AGB" project. Data verified by CTCPA's packaging expert.

General assumptions

For "PPSE" missing data, assumptions are based on CTCPA expertise 
Some multi-layer packaging (identified by CTCPA's expert) are modeled using a packaging solution from PACK AGB project. Nota bene the packaging format may be different.

Assumptions at each stage: 

Production
- Only the packaging material in contact with the product or ensuring the product's shelf life is modeled.
For example, in the case of cookies packaged in PP plastic bags (element 1), themselves packaged in a cardboard box (elements 2): (i) Element 2 is the heaviest / (ii) Element 1 is in contact with the product, so the PP material was taken into account.
- For multi-element and multi-layer packaging, the inventory calls for the material in contact with the product and for the quantity, an assumption has been made to take of the packaging solution (sum of all elements) and consider this value for this material.
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative material.

Processing
- Only the most representative process for the most representative packaging material is included.
For example, in the case of a multi-layer flexible film, only the extrusion process is modeled. The lamination process used to combine the various packaging layers was not included. 
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used for the most representative process.

Transport
- The assumptions of the PACK AGB project were applied
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material
- Ratios from France and Europe compiled in the PACK AGB project by packaging material were used (ADEME data, 2020).

End of life
- All plastic packaging is considered non-recycled (R2=0%).
To be able to affirm that the plastic packaging is recycled, it is necessary to consider the whole packaging solution (with all the elements and materials) and in this project the dataset only include a part of the packaging (proxy)
- Datasets created as part of the PACK AGB project were used, for the most representative packaging material. 
- The Circular FootPrint Formula was applied.

activityName: Cow milk {CA-QC}| milk production, from cow | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Cow milk {CA-QC}| milk production, from cow | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of conventional milk from dairy cows, in Québec (Canada), in 2009-2011. The module includes the consumption of feed, and the operation of cattle housing systems for the management of the dairy herd and the production of cow milk. The functional unit is 1 kg of Fat and Protein Corrected Milk (FPCM) raw milk from Québec dairy farms. The FPCM correction is made for a conversion to a 4.0% fat and 3.3% true protein content, following the equation provided by the International Dairy Federation (IDF): FPCM (kg/yr) = Production (kg/yr) x [0.1226 x Fat% + 0.0776 x Protein% + 0.2534]. Live animals (culled cows and calves) sold for slaughterhing are by-products, as well as solid and liquid manure.

https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/f08a0b12-8f8b-4f1d-8b52-1d688403d0cc [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

The average dairy farm in Québec produced 449400 L raw milk (at 4.06 kg/hL butterfat and 3.36 kg/hL protein), hence 469488 kg FCPM per farm. The average herd size over the year is: 57,7 milk cows (8137 kg FPCM/cow/year), 0.18 bulls, 0.39 young bulls, 1.11 veals male, 10.72 veals female, 12.56 bred heifers, 14.90 open heifers. Hence, the whole herd is worth 74 livestock units. 11 culled cows and 41 calves are sold for slaughter. The replacement rate is 32%. 91% of animals are housed in tie-stall systems, 9% in free-stall systems. With 6414 dairy farms, Québec milk production accounts for 38% of overall Canada production.

This dataset does not cover organic milk production in Quebec, which is marginal. 1.5% of overall Quebec dairy farms were organic-certified in 2010, and 1% of total milk produced in Québec in 2010 was organic milk (Fédération des Producteurs de lait du Québec; http://www.lait.org/en/interactive-faq/the-production.php). Furthermore, only 80% of organic milk ends up into organic-certified processed products (e.g. organic milk, yogurt, cheese)

44% of the manure is managed as solid manure (35% solid stored; 9% stockpiled) and 56% managed as liquid manure (35% liquid in open-pit with crust formation; 8% liquid in covered pit; 8% liquid in open-pit without crust; and 5% liquid in lagoon). According to these management figures and to the distribution of animal categories within the herd, emissions to the air from manure management have been calculated (in kg/kg FPCM): N2O (direct+indirect): 5,7866E-04 kg; NH3: 5,5310E-04 kg; CH4: 5,5198E-03 kg.

None

Production volume: 3011295488 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts from the reception and storage of feed materials, and dairy herd housing.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the provision of milk at farm, ready-to-deliver. The dataset includes the consumption of feed; the livestock management operations (including bedding, drinking water, milking equipment, cleaning products and water, ammonia and dinitrogen oxyde emissions from housing, and methane emissions from enteric fermentation), manure management emissions; energy and buildings (including electricity for dairying, cattle housing and milk parlour equipment and buildings, and gasoline for regular operations) necessary for the operation of a typical dairy farm. The dataset does not include fodder and feed production and processing into meal for animals, litter production, manure management operations (however, emissions are accounted for); nor milk transportation beyond the farm gate (e.g. to dairy processing plants). Also, the dataset does not include particulate matter emissions, nor any drugs used on the dairy farm, because of the lack of data available on quantities and content. In terms of mass, drugs represent much less than 1% of inputs.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Québec
Technology level: Current
Technology: Data and assumptions are intended to reflect current equipment, processes, and market conditions.
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Period indicated in the reference. 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Vanilla, cured and dried beans, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg cured and dried vanilla.

System Boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. This dataset covers the process of vanilla curing, including blanching, sweating, and drying of the green vanilla beans. The input green vanilla beans, as well as the energy and water use are included. Yield is 6.5 kg green beans per kg cured vanilla. Packaging is not included.

Geography: Madagascar

Technology: Traditional bleaching, sweating and sun-drying as practiced in Madagascar and India and described in the following websites, accessed December 2018.
http://www.varanashi.com/vanilla_processing.html
http://www.provagourmet.us/the-vanilla-process

It is assumed that water heated for 30-kg batches amounts to 90 L, with 5% loss for each batch (evaporation and extracted with the beans, dried). Water is completed regularly and thrown away after 10 batches in a row (10 times 5% loss). So 90 L are used and returned to surface water, and 45 L are used in addition and evaporated / evacuated with the blanched beans and dried. Total 135 L for 300 kg dried beans.
Water is heated with firewood from 20°C to 65°C, assuming 40% energy loss each batch (in addition to energy loss via water loss) because of the heat needed to heat the beans (0.33 kg/L, assuming similar heat capacity to water) and other losses. Firewood related LUC is ignored at this stage. The situation in Madagascar is critical in this regard, but firewood can be sourced from plantations planted on degraded land being restored, so refinement is needed.

The use of clean blankets is critical for the success of the sweating process. The cleaning is done in hot water with similar assumptions as above, plus the following: One blanket is used for each 30-kg batch (which becomes lighter while drying, obviously). Cleaning 1 blanket requires about 5 L of water at 70°C. 10% of that water is evaporated.

Shade drying is done in a room filled with wooden boxes (with 1 batch in each) and artificially ventilated 24x7 during 2 to 3 months. Assumptions are made on the number of boxes and the power of the ventilation system.

Time: Data from 2010 - 2018

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7, Good quality

activityName: Peanut {CN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {CN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 3.5 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 80-27-28 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 11.25 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in China amounts to 10% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 15861245952 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for China
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Rice, non-basmati {CN}| rice production, non-basmati | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rice, non-basmati {CN}| rice production, non-basmati | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of rice grains, at standard water content required for storage (13.1%). The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 6.6 t/ha. The data are representative for a double rice cropping system in Southern China (Hunan province), representing the largest rice-producing province of China. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 72-23-26 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 3.55 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of rice produced in China amounts to 28% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing rice produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:

 - rice production, CN, 2009 - 2012 (18a7fdeb-0fa4-4d9b-a4b7-c96037c23593)]

Production volume: 211090817024 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of rice grains and subsequent burning of crop residues. A winter fallow is following the harvest of late rice, where no irrigation is applied. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: rotary tillage, the application of pesticides and fertilizers, irrigation and harvesting, and on-farm transport. Rice seedlings are transplanted manually by throwing the seedlings in the standing water. Paddy rice is grown under flooded conditions (~40-50 mm water depth) for the entire growing season except for the aeration stage and one week prior to harvest (i.e. ~80 days under flooded conditions per crop cycle). Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. In the considered region of China, rice is produced in a double rice cropping system (two crop cycles). Therefore, an average of the two crop cycles was used for the considered inputs. The inputs of seeds, irrigation water, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) grain drying, as no information was available and b) the production of rice seedlings (seeds are used as input). 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for China
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

This dataset represents white cabbage production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 48 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 5.25 months.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 28512262144 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 4.5 months and it's use of electricity.  
And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Walnut, in shell, dried, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of walnut, in shell, dried, at the farm (in practice, dehusking and drying generally take place in a separate facility). 6.72 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 10660 m3/ha). According to Yilmaz 2017, the total fresh walnut, with its green husk is 2.65 times the in-shell dried walnut.

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of seedling production and planting, fertilizer and pesticide application, irrigation and harvest. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change (LUC) are considered. The processing of dehusking and drying is also included, even if occuring at plant and not directly at farm, to obtain in-shell dried walnuts. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 25 years. 

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.2, Excellent quality

Geography: USA

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2016-2017

Data sources: 
- Grant 2017: Grant J A, Caprile J L, Doll, D A, Murdock J, 2017. Sample costs to establish an orchard and produce walnuts, San Joaquin Valley - North, Late leafing - lateral bearing. UC Davis Department of agricultural and resources economics report. Downloaded on https://coststudyfiles.ucdavis.edu/uploads/cs_public/1d/05/1d05d59d-706e-4937-8e05-5563b7468e23/2017-walnutssjvn-final_draft.pdf, August 2019.
- Yilmaz 2017: Yilmaz S, Akça Y, Saçlik S, 2017. Green husk and Inshell biomass production capabilities of six walnut cultivars. J Internation Scientific Publications, Agriculture & Food. Vol 5. 
- Various websites consulted for the concentration in active ingredients of the pesticides, detailed for each pesticide flow on input/output tab.

The comments below were part of the CN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of tea. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1.1 t/ha. The data are representative for tea production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 35-10-10 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 10.63 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of tea produced in China amounts to 15% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing tea produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 3.2 (i.e. fair quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1436769536 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), and the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: fertiliser and pesticide application, and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
   Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

activityName: Aluminium, primary, ingot {RoW}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Aluminium, primary, ingot {RoW}| aluminium production, primary, ingot | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production of 1kg of primary aluminium ingot. Molten aluminium produced from the electrolytic process is tapped from reduction cells, weighed, sampled and analysed before it is poured into a holding furnace and heated to approximately 750°C using natural gas as a fuel. Alloying elements, such as magnesium, silicon and manganese, for additional strength, corrosion resistance and other properties, are added to the aluminium. It is typically at this point in the process that clean, sorted scrap can also be added but for the purposes of this dataset, scrap remelting is excluded. During furnace charging and preparation, aluminium dross (a thick liquid or solid phase) forms at the surface of molten aluminium. This mixture of aluminium oxides is remelted to recover the aluminium that would otherwise be lost. Metallurgical analysis verifies that the metal meets customer specifications before the molten, alloyed (or pure, unalloyed) aluminium is cast into products of specific dimensions, before being weighed, bundled and strapped ready for transport. Original dataset included some alloying elements.  These were replaced by liquid aluminium to generate a theoretical 100% aluminium ingot.

For more information on the process, please go to 

http://primary.world-aluminium.org/index.php?id=285

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

Production volume: 2096486016 kg
Included activities start: The unit process begins with the unloading of process material to their storage areas on site.  The operations covered by this dataset include:
* pre-treatment of hot metal
* recovery and handling of internal process scrap
* batching, metal treatment and casting operations
* homogenizing, sawing and packaging activities
* maintenance and repair of plant and equipment
* treatment of process air, liquids and solids.
* production of infrastructure (through rough estimate) was also added.
Included activities end: The output of this unit process is packaged aluminium ingots, wrought alloy.

Two references were weighed to best represent the French market. They are marketed both under own brand and under private label.
The weight of 170g of product used was obtained by averaging two references of 160g and 180g. The weight of the packaging corresponds to the average of the weighed packaging.

The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE).

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html .

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,25; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France.
